messages: [{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-09-24 04:01:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-09-24 13:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-09-25 03:37:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-09-26 14:11:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-24 04:01:10.000000000', 'message': 'Add --cpuset-cpus support for both Docker and Podman

Limit the specific CPUs or cores a container can use.

If cpuset-cpus is configured in the container layout, then the value
will be used when running the container cli with --cpuset-cpus.
If 'all' is used as a value, we'll then take all available cpus,
computed by: "0-" + str(psutil.cpu_count()-1)

If unset (default), the cpuset-cpus value is computed by using psutil with a
new function which returns a comma-separated list range of CPUs that a
container can use.

This parameter is particulary useful for NFV:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1750781
Indeed, for NFV workloads, in order to achieve 0 packet loss, linux processes,
ovs-dpdk (if applicable) and VMs are isolated thanks to kernel args (isolcpus)
and tuned profiles (cpu-partitioning).

(cherry picked from commit 5e88de63f5763da94d26ffcd87c609527986e954)

Change-Id: Id4739e48bb4706a47a16ed4339c5d0ff3d8ecaa2
'}, {'created': '2019-09-24 13:56:47.000000000', 'message': 'Add --cpuset-cpus support for both Docker and Podman

Limit the specific CPUs or cores a container can use.

If cpuset-cpus is configured in the container layout, then the value
will be used when running the container cli with --cpuset-cpus.
If 'all' is used as a value, we'll then take all available cpus,
computed by: "0-" + str(psutil.cpu_count()-1)

If unset (default), the cpuset-cpus value is computed by using psutil with a
new function which returns a comma-separated list range of CPUs that a
container can use.

This parameter is particulary useful for NFV:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1750781
Indeed, for NFV workloads, in order to achieve 0 packet loss, linux processes,
ovs-dpdk (if applicable) and VMs are isolated thanks to kernel args (isolcpus)
and tuned profiles (cpu-partitioning).

(cherry picked from commit 5e88de63f5763da94d26ffcd87c609527986e954)

Change-Id: Id4739e48bb4706a47a16ed4339c5d0ff3d8ecaa2
'}]
commit_message:
Add --cpuset-cpus support for both Docker and Podman

Limit the specific CPUs or cores a container can use.

If cpuset-cpus is configured in the container layout, then the value
will be used when running the container cli with --cpuset-cpus.
If 'all' is used as a value, we'll then take all available cpus,
computed by: "0-" + str(psutil.cpu_count()-1)

If unset (default), the cpuset-cpus value is computed by using psutil with a
new function which returns a comma-separated list range of CPUs that a
container can use.

This parameter is particulary useful for NFV:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1750781
Indeed, for NFV workloads, in order to achieve 0 packet loss, linux processes,
ovs-dpdk (if applicable) and VMs are isolated thanks to kernel args (isolcpus)
and tuned profiles (cpu-partitioning).

(cherry picked from commit 5e88de63f5763da94d26ffcd87c609527986e954)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-26 08:27:58.000000000', 'message': "Add new workarounds mechanism to apply workarounds via Ansible.

The tripleo-upgrade has a workarounds logic which allows us to
apply patches or specific modifications prior and after some of
the upgrade steps. However, if these workarouds need to be applied
in the overcloud nodes, the only way to do it was via a bash script
which would iterate over the nodes and apply the patch or perform a
change on each of the nodes.

This patch adds a new workarounds field: ansible. When this option
will be present in the workaround and it will be different than an
empty string then the workaround will be aplied via Ansible in the
nodes specified in the ansible field. This ansible option needs to
be used in combination with the command one, as the command will
be transformed in a shell Ansible task which will be executed in
the nodes passed in the ansible option.

Example:
pre_overcloud_upgrade_prepare_workarounds:
- set_root_password:
    patch: false
    basedir: ''
    id: ''
    ansible: 'overcloud'
    command: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

will turn into a set_root_password.yaml Ansible playbook under
~/ansible_workarounds:

cat ~/ansible_workarounds/set_root_password.yaml
- hosts: overcloud
  tasks:
    - name: set_root_password workaround
      shell: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

When executing the workarounds, a new bash function ansible_patch
has been included which will take care of executing the generated
Ansible playbook.

Also, an optional input parameter could be passed to workarounds.sh,
when passed, it will be taken as input for the --limit option when
executing ansible-playbook. This way, we can execute a workaround
specifically in a server, instead of running it in all of them.

Change-Id: I421ebecfc5504ac2fd225de0c4fb0cbf735bbdaf
(cherry picked from commit e582d2f30473f714260c620d5c0d3807009aa797)
"}, {'created': '2019-09-26 08:38:27.000000000', 'message': "Add new workarounds mechanism to apply workarounds via Ansible.

which would iterate over the nodes and apply the patch or perform a
change on each of the nodes.

This patch adds a new workarounds field: ansible_hosts. When this
option will be present in the workaround and it will be different
than an empty string then the workaround will be aplied via Ansible in
the nodes specified in that ansible_hosts field. This ansible_hosts
option needs to be used in combination with the command one, as
the command will be transformed in a shell Ansible task which will
be executed in the nodes passed in the ansible_hosts option.

Example:

- set_root_password:
    patch: false
    basedir: ''
    id: ''
    ansible_hosts: 'overcloud'
    command: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

will turn into a set_root_password.yaml Ansible playbook under

cat ~/ansible_workarounds/set_root_password.yaml
- hosts: overcloud
  tasks:
    - name: set_root_password workaround
      shell: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

When executing the workarounds, a new bash function ansible_patch
has been included which will take care of executing the generated
Ansible playbook.

Also, an optional input parameter could be passed to workarounds.sh,
when passed, it will be taken as input for the --limit option when
executing ansible-playbook. This way, we can execute a workaround
specifically in a server, instead of running it in all of them.

Change-Id: I421ebecfc5504ac2fd225de0c4fb0cbf735bbdaf
(cherry picked from commit e582d2f30473f714260c620d5c0d3807009aa797)
"}]
commit_message:
Add new workarounds mechanism to apply workarounds via Ansible.

The tripleo-upgrade has a workarounds logic which allows us to
apply patches or specific modifications prior and after some of
the upgrade steps. However, if these workarouds need to be applied
in the overcloud nodes, the only way to do it was via a bash script
which would iterate over the nodes and apply the patch or perform a
change on each of the nodes.

This patch adds a new workarounds field: ansible_hosts. When this
option will be present in the workaround and it will be different
than an empty string then the workaround will be aplied via Ansible in
the nodes specified in that ansible_hosts field. This ansible_hosts
option needs to be used in combination with the command one, as
the command will be transformed in a shell Ansible task which will
be executed in the nodes passed in the ansible_hosts option.

Example:
pre_overcloud_upgrade_prepare_workarounds:
- set_root_password:
    patch: false
    basedir: ''
    id: ''
    ansible_hosts: 'overcloud'
    command: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

will turn into a set_root_password.yaml Ansible playbook under
~/ansible_workarounds:

cat ~/ansible_workarounds/set_root_password.yaml
- hosts: overcloud
  tasks:
    - name: set_root_password workaround
      shell: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

When executing the workarounds, a new bash function ansible_patch
has been included which will take care of executing the generated
Ansible playbook.

Also, an optional input parameter could be passed to workarounds.sh,
when passed, it will be taken as input for the --limit option when
executing ansible-playbook. This way, we can execute a workaround
specifically in a server, instead of running it in all of them.

Change-Id: I421ebecfc5504ac2fd225de0c4fb0cbf735bbdaf
(cherry picked from commit e582d2f30473f714260c620d5c0d3807009aa797)

subject: Handle when ceph_osds is a dictionary or a list.
messages: [{'account_id': 26343, 'date': '2019-09-25 12:18:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 20775, 'date': '2019-09-26 10:50:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20775, 'date': '2019-09-26 15:37:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-25 12:18:14.000000000', 'message': "Handle when ceph_osds is a dictionary or a list.

The ceph_osds variable is obtained from the ceph configuration
and it seems it can be a dictionary formed by the osds directories
as keys, example {'/dev/vdc': {}, '/dev/vdb': {}, '/dev/vdf': {},
'/dev/vde': {}, '/dev/vdd': {}} .
For that reason, we need to differentiate when the variable is
a list or a dictionary, as otherwise the loop variable won't be
able to iterate over the values.

Change-Id: Ib7aded0ff3668079dbe43cc3fbfa6a7e067cec83
Closes-Bug: #1844974
(cherry picked from commit 75290252d7bd22540a10a47ba6f5477d85c5a542)
"}]
commit_message:
Handle when ceph_osds is a dictionary or a list.

The ceph_osds variable is obtained from the ceph configuration
and it seems it can be a dictionary formed by the osds directories
as keys, example {'/dev/vdc': {}, '/dev/vdb': {}, '/dev/vdf': {},
'/dev/vde': {}, '/dev/vdd': {}} .
For that reason, we need to differentiate when the variable is
a list or a dictionary, as otherwise the loop variable won't be
able to iterate over the values.

Change-Id: Ib7aded0ff3668079dbe43cc3fbfa6a7e067cec83
Closes-Bug: #1844974
(cherry picked from commit 75290252d7bd22540a10a47ba6f5477d85c5a542)

[{'created': '2019-09-23 13:46:48.000000000', 'message': "Fix selinux context for glance-api

Remove the z flag from glance-api's service directory. The service
directory does not need to be shared with other containers, and
podman fails to apply setting with glance is using NFS (i.e.
/var/lib/glance/images is a mount point).

Also update the NFS mount options to use svirt_sandbox_file_t, which
is consistent with the parent service directory.

Closes-Bug: #1834857
Closes-Bug: #1844465
Change-Id: I7e135615fb53815ce14a3bcfec42b28f86d6dbae
(cherry picked from commit aa1f4bf62156fa5e72b8171702acf3db755a67d8)

commit_message:
Fix selinux context for glance-api

Remove the z flag from glance-api's service directory. The service
directory does not need to be shared with other containers, and
podman fails to apply setting with glance is using NFS (i.e.
/var/lib/glance/images is a mount point).

Also update the NFS mount options to use svirt_sandbox_file_t, which
is consistent with the parent service directory.

Closes-Bug: #1834857
Closes-Bug: #1844465
Change-Id: I7e135615fb53815ce14a3bcfec42b28f86d6dbae
(cherry picked from commit aa1f4bf62156fa5e72b8171702acf3db755a67d8)

commit_message:
Add profile_tasks to ansible runs

Adding profile_tasks to the default ansible.cfg so we get task timing in
the output.

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/plugins/callback/profile_tasks.html

Change-Id: I6e5ff1f59e8179133099f3b9e405d66aab24be78
(cherry picked from commit bbd92d6723372dc2669e1db05ac34e18d44302e7)

I am fine with the implementation, but it would be good if the --rm option is not used when in Debug enabled deployment. Would like to know your opinion.'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2019-09-23 08:14:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I am fine with the implementation, but it would be good if the --rm
 > option is not used when in Debug enabled deployment. Would like to
 > know your opinion.

hmm maybe? Although we already had tons of issues with podman and "ghost containers" (see related LP). Doing so would not improve CI, since it's running with said Debug flag afaik. There's still a way to keep the containers using the "keep_container" flag though. Would that be sufficient for manual deploy?'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2019-09-23 10:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> There's still a way to keep the containers using the "keep_container" flag though. Would that be sufficient for manual deploy?

keep_container is specific to a container. When there is an issue, it has to be added and then deploymed. I agree that we can use it in general Debug mode as it will affect CI. So, I am good with current code as is.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-09-25 17:13:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-09-26 12:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add "--rm" to the container "run" command

Doing so should help preventing the "ghost container" effect we
described in #1840691.
It is still possible to keep failed containers, if we pass
"keep_container: True" to the container-puppet.py script env.

We still keep the "container_rm()" method, since it apparently can help
ensuring all is actually removed in the end.

Change-Id: I1029fb24491b867616293f8487abc2b5295bca57
Related-Bug: #1840691

commit_message:
Fix delete arq 403 failed and skip non-admin arq policy check

Normal user delete arq give 403 error. The error info[1]:

Client-side error: Access was denied to the following resource: cyborg:arq:delete

[1]. https://storage.gra1.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_fa3/670999/12/experimental/cyborg-tempest/fa3f4fa/controller/logs/screen-cyborg-api.txt.gz

The reason to skip non-admin arq check because that we lack[2] some code
about _get_resource[3][4][5]. We need to improve this and then open this check.

[2]. https://github.com/openstack/cyborg/search?q=_get_resource&unscoped_q=_get_resource
[3]. https://github.com/openstack/cyborg/blob/master/cyborg/common/policy.py#L235
[4]. https://github.com/openstack/mogan/blob/1c9b721b5cb037ac68c9cfdb41669945a25463ff/mogan/common/policy.py#L305
[5]. https://github.com/openstack/mogan/blob/1c9b721b5cb037ac68c9cfdb41669945a25463ff/mogan/api/controllers/v1/servers.py#L59

Co-Authored-By: chenke <chen.ke14@zte.com.cn>

Change-Id: I45e4dae33e6c3806b8680abfe266cfeb8cb80f9f

commit_message:
[wip] simple-init : don't use network.service for centos8

As described inline, network.service doesn't exist on Centos 8

(wip until we can confirm networking working ...)

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I7eb80c733003d960b64deda708ec8db56a871b16

commit_message:
[Glance] add job-metadefs-load

Glance provide default list of metadata definitions in /etc/glance/metadefs
directory. The patch adds job that will load those defaults definitions.
The job is enabled by default.

Change-Id: Ib3ab20a9a7f73b568b029b06101cf4e5e2473716

subject: HA: fix <service>_restart_bundle with minor update workflow
messages:
[{'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-09-16 09:24:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-09-25 08:46:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-09-25 16:13:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

check-rdo'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-09-25 20:25:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

RDO job seems to be hitting https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1845166 atm'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-09-26 09:59:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-16 09:24:16.000000000', 'message': "HA: fix <service>_restart_bundle with minor update workflow

For each HA service we have a paunch container <service>_restart_bundle
which is started by paunch whenever config files changes during stack
deploy/update. This container runs a pcs command on a single node to
restart all the service's containers (e.g. all galera on all controllers).
By design, when it is run, configs have already been regenerated by the
deploy tasks on all nodes.

For minor updates, the workflow runs differently: all the steps of the
deploy tasks are run one node after the other, so when
<service>_restart_bundle is called, there is no guarantee that the
service's configs have been regenerated on all the nodes yet.

To fix the wrong restart behaviour, only restart local containers when
running during a minor update. And run once per node. When the minor
update workflow calls <service>_restart_container, we still have the
guarantee that the config files are already regenerated locally.

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@acksyn.org>
Co-Authored-By: Luca Miccini <lmiccini@redhat.com>

(cherry picked from commit 44283e9222793a8b8d019a98868d932dccc2b253
and removed services undefined in Queens)

Change-Id: I92d4ddf2feeac06ce14468ae928c283f3fd04f45
Closes-Bug: #1841629
"}]
commit_message:
HA: fix <service>_restart_bundle with minor update workflow

For each HA service we have a paunch container <service>_restart_bundle
which is started by paunch whenever config files changes during stack
deploy/update. This container runs a pcs command on a single node to
restart all the service's containers (e.g. all galera on all controllers).
By design, when it is run, configs have already been regenerated by the
deploy tasks on all nodes.

For minor updates, the workflow runs differently: all the steps of the
deploy tasks are run one node after the other, so when
<service>_restart_bundle is called, there is no guarantee that the
service's configs have been regenerated on all the nodes yet.

To fix the wrong restart behaviour, only restart local containers when
running during a minor update. And run once per node. When the minor
update workflow calls <service>_restart_container, we still have the
guarantee that the config files are already regenerated locally.

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@acksyn.org>
Co-Authored-By: Luca Miccini <lmiccini@redhat.com>

(cherry picked from commit 44283e9222793a8b8d019a98868d932dccc2b253
and removed services undefined in Queens)

Change-Id: I92d4ddf2feeac06ce14468ae928c283f3fd04f45
Closes-Bug: #1841629

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ib7785dfacc8b83ead5c2561fa6d55cc0e7f6b90c

messages: [{'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-09-27 01:22:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-25 08:46:33.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ia9e0181e1013445b62abd8128c189eafa83906db
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ia9e0181e1013445b62abd8128c189eafa83906db

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-17 21:24:02.000000000', 'message': 'Fix validation of role assignment subtree list

Without this patch, if a project ID is not passed as query argument, a
target of {} is passed to the enforcer and causes a type error to be
raised ("'NoneType' object is not callable") which then is emitted as a
validation error to the user rather than as a server error. This patch
fixes the issue by correctly passing in None as the default target,
which is what the enforcer expects, which then allows the validation to
continue and return a more helpful error message about the required
query parameter.

Change-Id: If7f0fa4dd072b0f00172161da4f7b91f8c1e1f10

commit_message:
Fix validation of role assignment subtree list

Without this patch, if a project ID is not passed as query argument, a
target of {} is passed to the enforcer and causes a type error to be
raised ("'NoneType' object is not callable") which then is emitted as a
validation error to the user rather than as a server error. This patch
fixes the issue by correctly passing in None as the default target,
which is what the enforcer expects, which then allows the validation to
continue and return a more helpful error message about the required
query parameter.

Change-Id: If7f0fa4dd072b0f00172161da4f7b91f8c1e1f10

subject: sharder: Keep cleaving on empty shard ranges
messages:
[{'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-08-12 06:34:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-17 00:29:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

Thanks for getting a patch up for this so quickly! I really like the approach; seems like a good balance between making sure that we really do cleave off any rows that may exist, but we still make much faster progress through the DB.

Just a couple questions for now, I'll try to test it out manually a bit next week."}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-08-19 00:24:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Thanks Tim.

Will look into your comments :)'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-08-20 07:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-21 05:31:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

recheck'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-21 15:38:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-08-21 16:43:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)

I'd love to hear if anyone has any alternative ideas on how we might approach this bug?

I don't think I can offer an effective review without spending significantly more time here - the requirements and restrictions of the existing design may be more subtle than I can see without fighting with alternative solutions first hand.

But this implementation is using exceptions for flow control - which I would like to discourage - if at ALL possible (N.B. the related bug doesn't have a priority assigned; so I'm taking for granted we have some leeway to address the defect while simultaneously improving the existing code)

I think the code here is significantly more complicated, and I wasn't able to follow the change nearly as well as I was able to understand the bug report.  Complicated code is expected of course when we're taking on more complexity - but the diff line count ratio from code to tests doesn't seem to reflect the increase in complexity.

What's going on, what's our goals, what are our options - what can I do to help?"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-28 00:54:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> But this implementation is using exceptions for flow control - which I would like to discourage - if at ALL possible

Yeah, that's a good thought... and it gets more important on py3, as it muddies the real error when things go off the rails. Prompted me to write https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/557335465 when I'd go and accidentally introduce a NameError or something while I was porting the proxy."}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-08-28 06:32:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

kk, fair point. It was an easy way of adding the functionality without touching too much of the inception like code.

Will have another go of reworking it the code to better fit our needs. thanks @clayg and @timburke :)

I'll mark it WIP until I can push a new patchset"}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-08-30 04:01:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-09-04 03:03:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2019-09-26 19:41:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-12 06:34:03.000000000', 'message': "sharder: Keep cleaving on empty shard ranges

When a container is being cleaved there is a possiblity that we're
dealing with an empty or near empty container created on a handoff node.
These containers may have a valid list of shard ranges, so would need
to cleave to the new shards.
Currently, when using a `cleave_batch_size` that is smaller then the
number of shard ranges on the cleaving container, these containers will
have to take a few shard passes to shard, even though there maybe
nothing in them.

This is worse if a really large container is sharding, and due to being
slow, error limitted a node causing a new container on a handoff
location. This empty container would have a large number of shard ranges
and could take a _very_ long time to shard away, slowing the process
down.

This patch eliminates the issue by detecting when no objects are
returned for a shard range. In which case it'll throw a
`ZeroCleavedObjectsException` which will:

  - Log
  - Not replicate the empty temp shard container sitting in a
    handoff location
  - Not count the shard range in the `cleave_batch_size` count
  - Update the cleaving context so sharding can move forward

Change-Id: Id338f6c3187f93454bcdf025a32a073284a4a159
Closes-Bug: #1839355
"}, {'created': '2019-08-20 07:05:49.000000000', 'message': "sharder: Keep cleaving on empty shard ranges

When a container is being cleaved there is a possiblity that we're
dealing with an empty or near empty container created on a handoff node.
These containers may have a valid list of shard ranges, so would need
to cleave to the new shards.
Currently, when using a `cleave_batch_size` that is smaller then the
number of shard ranges on the cleaving container, these containers will
have to take a few shard passes to shard, even though there maybe
nothing in them.

This is worse if a really large container is sharding, and due to being
slow, error limitted a node causing a new container on a handoff
location. This empty container would have a large number of shard ranges
and could take a _very_ long time to shard away, slowing the process
down.

This patch eliminates the issue by detecting when no objects are
returned for a shard range. In which case it'll throw a
`ZeroCleavedObjectsException` which will:

  - Log
  - Not replicate the empty temp shard container sitting in a
    handoff location
  - Not count the shard range in the `cleave_batch_size` count
  - Update the cleaving context so sharding can move forward

If there already is a shard range DB existing on a handoff node to use
then the sharder wont skip it, even if there are no objects, it'll
replicate it and treat it as normal, including using a `cleave_batch_size`
slot.

Change-Id: Id338f6c3187f93454bcdf025a32a073284a4a159
Closes-Bug: #1839355
"}, {'created': '2019-08-30 04:01:52.000000000', 'message': "sharder: Keep cleaving on empty shard ranges

commit_message:
sharder: Keep cleaving on empty shard ranges

When a container is being cleaved there is a possiblity that we're
dealing with an empty or near empty container created on a handoff node.
These containers may have a valid list of shard ranges, so would need
to cleave to the new shards.
Currently, when using a `cleave_batch_size` that is smaller then the
number of shard ranges on the cleaving container, these containers will
have to take a few shard passes to shard, even though there maybe
nothing in them.

This is worse if a really large container is sharding, and due to being
slow, error limitted a node causing a new container on a handoff
location. This empty container would have a large number of shard ranges
and could take a _very_ long time to shard away, slowing the process
down.

This patch eliminates the issue by detecting when no objects are
returned for a shard range. The `_cleave_shard_range` method now
returns 3 possible results:

  - CLEAVE_SUCCESS
  - CLEAVE_FAILED
  - CLEAVE_EMPTY

They all are pretty self explanitory. When `CLEAVE_EMPTY` is returned
the code will:

  - Log
  - Not replicate the empty temp shard container sitting in a
    handoff location
  - Not count the shard range in the `cleave_batch_size` count
  - Update the cleaving context so sharding can move forward

If there already is a shard range DB existing on a handoff node to use
then the sharder wont skip it, even if there are no objects, it'll
replicate it and treat it as normal, including using a `cleave_batch_size`
slot.

Change-Id: Id338f6c3187f93454bcdf025a32a073284a4a159
Closes-Bug: #1839355

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I6c67881152fa8226eaf62c91c483ba6128caf7ee

commit_message:
Define default netpol for openstack-exporter

This change adds default network policy definitions for ingress/egress
in the prometheus-openstack-exporter chart to allow all traffic.

This also adds a netpol value override to enable network policy for
various network policy checks.

Change-Id: If1314420d5038174e8641c9809de65b23853d3f3

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-18 08:46:23.000000000', 'message': "Handle events in separate IDL instance

While setting the event handler lock in OvnNbIdlForLb
we found that on each Octavia API call exception
was raised that the IDL has not aquired OVNDB lock [0].

It is because when we set the event lock name it is
required to be acquired on each transaction, even on
the one passed by Octavia API, which shouldn't be
blocking one [1].

The second issue was cached NB DB connection within the same
process [2]. We overcome this by using other idl
implementation that utilize modified
networking_ovn.ovsdb.impl_idl_ovn.Backend.

So to address this issue I initialize second IDL that
watches only for events and has the lock name set. First
instance of OvnNbIdlForLb is used only for handling
Octavia API requests. Second has the lock name set and
is cached by OvnProviderHelper class attribute, that makes
the event mechanism work.

While long-living agent driver would be released
the second OvnNbIdlForLb object could be used in OVN agent
driver process in order to handle events there and then
we could stop using second IDL in the OvnProviderHelper.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/master/ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/transaction.py#L102
[1] https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/master/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L445
[2] https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/68d462d355a9c9f7e6b12f08f4dfb0b0b3d443b2/ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/__init__.py#L51

Change-Id: I6534ac7777cf2a1216c65110704c675d5160b051
Story: 2006196
(cherry picked from commit c637f341261499f90b4fa29523f890c7faeec9fe)
"}, {'created': '2019-09-19 10:31:12.000000000', 'message': "Handle events in separate IDL instance

commit_message:
Handle events in separate IDL instance

While setting the event handler lock in OvnNbIdlForLb
we found that on each Octavia API call exception
was raised that the IDL has not aquired OVNDB lock [0].

It is because when we set the event lock name it is
required to be acquired on each transaction, even on
the one passed by Octavia API, which shouldn't be
blocking one [1].

The second issue was cached NB DB connection within the same
process [2]. We overcome this by using other idl
implementation that utilize modified
networking_ovn.ovsdb.impl_idl_ovn.Backend.

So to address this issue I initialize second IDL that
watches only for events and has the lock name set. First
instance of OvnNbIdlForLb is used only for handling
Octavia API requests. Second has the lock name set and
is cached by OvnProviderHelper class attribute, that makes
the event mechanism work.

While long-living agent driver would be released
the second OvnNbIdlForLb object could be used in OVN agent
driver process in order to handle events there and then
we could stop using second IDL in the OvnProviderHelper.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/master/ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/transaction.py#L102
[1] https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/master/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L445
[2] https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/68d462d355a9c9f7e6b12f08f4dfb0b0b3d443b2/ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/__init__.py#L51

Change-Id: I6534ac7777cf2a1216c65110704c675d5160b051
Story: 2006196
(cherry picked from commit c637f341261499f90b4fa29523f890c7faeec9fe)

commit_message:
Reset forced_destination before migration at a proper time

Resetting was in place but it was done after the retry filter is
populated in the MigrationTask by the populate_retry call. This
patch moves the reset code before the call to populate_retry as
to allow retries.

Change-Id: I8290e890a36cf5a8f409ab8a50e7c72f7ae15025
Closed-Bug: #1845291

subject: python-tackerclient 0.16.1
messages:
[{'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2019-09-23 06:43:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-23 09:08:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Looks positive. We do have processes to release at certain times for certain deliverables, and I am not sure why this doesn't follow our processes/timings? Could you explain it for me, please?"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-09-23 14:46:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Since we are under requirements freeze (since the deadline to release client libraries 10 days ago), if this release is necessary for the train release we will need approval from the requirements team. Could you open a thread on the openstack-discuss ML asking for [requirements] to grant an exception ?'}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2019-09-25 21:32:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Jean, @Thierry,

I had released as per the schedules of client lib freeze and already cut stable/train branch.
Later on, we fixes some bugs and cherry-picked those in stable/train. In this patch I am releasing those fixes. 
Please let me know, if any gap.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-09-26 09:01:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Dharmendra: the issue here is that as we try to sync requirements across all of the Train release, consumers of python-tackerclient might have to re-release to pick the new requirements up.

Decision becomes a trade-off between the pain of not having the fix in the initial release and the pain of re-releasing. We just need a requirements freeze exception thread on the mailing-list to discuss this trade-off publicly, before we can grant the exception.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-26 12:00:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Please post a link to the FFE if you want to get this out as part of the coordinated train release.

The other option is that you wait and as soon as the requirements freeze is over, do a normal stable release. Unless this is blocking major functionality for Train, I would recommend just waiting a few weeks for that.'}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2019-09-26 19:31:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Thierry, @sean,

Earlier I though, as its a bug fix(not features) so no feature freeze exception will be required. But now I understand your points, and as those fixes required, so I send mail for requirements freeze exception thread on the mailing-list. 
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-September/009718.html'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2019-09-27 00:23:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

responded on the list, ffe approved'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-27 00:27:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Remove limit policies from policy.v3cloudsample.json

By incorporating system-scope and default roles, we've effectively
made these policies obsolete. We can simplify what we maintain and
provide a more consistent, unified view of default limit
behavior by removing them.

Change-Id: Ie0f333a9e8b60154711a24ba7d9ade531217eb71
Closes-Bug: 1805880

commit_message:
Functional reproduction for bug 1845291

Nova does not try to re-schedule a migration if the original boot was
done with --availability-zone <az:host> or <az::node>.

Related-Bug #1845291

Change-Id: Id78627c5c08090de6220249a5f44d26bf32724af

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-24 08:45:35.000000000', 'message': 'Configure keepalived interfaces according to config file

"keepalived" process stops running if it does not find any of the
tracked interfaces correctly configured. To prevent this in
"KeepalivedManagerTestCase" test cases, "eth0" is set up and an IP
address is assigned.

Change-Id: Ibd4ef7b0db5b6830383fffcac685b9c709aae350

commit_message:
Configure keepalived interfaces according to config file

"keepalived" process stops running if it does not find any of the
tracked interfaces correctly configured. To prevent this in
"KeepalivedManagerTestCase" test cases, "eth0" is set up and an IP
address is assigned.

Change-Id: Ibd4ef7b0db5b6830383fffcac685b9c709aae350
Closes-Bug: #1845150
Related-Bug: #1830232

'}, {'created': '2019-09-03 16:38:32.000000000', 'message': "Octavia certificate distribution

Current copy certificates task works only if octavia_cert_setup_host is
localhost, because it copies from local path. See bug 1842117

To fix this issue certs are slurped and registered after they are
created.
If octavia_cert_setup_host is 'localhost' cert variables are
registered to task_vars scope.
If octavia_cert_setup_host is one of the octavia containers or utility
containers, i.e. setup host exists in inventory cert variables are
registered to hostvars[octavia_cert_setup_host] i.e hostvars scope.
Certs facts are set according to octavia_cert_setup_host value.
Certs distribution play copies certs from certs facts to each octavia
conatainer.

Change-Id: I0906c7cf80c3345fb993a71fe190fa2f6baa55e4
Closes-Bug: 1842117

commit_message:
Octavia certificate distribution

Current copy certificates task works only if octavia_cert_setup_host is
localhost, because it copies from local path. See bug 1842117

To fix this issue certs are slurped and registered after they are
created.
If octavia_cert_setup_host is 'localhost' cert variables are
registered to task_vars scope.
If octavia_cert_setup_host is one of the octavia containers or utility
containers, i.e. setup host exists in inventory cert variables are
registered to hostvars[octavia_cert_setup_host] i.e hostvars scope.
Certs facts are set according to octavia_cert_setup_host value.
Certs distribution play copies certs from certs facts to each octavia
conatainer.

Change-Id: I0906c7cf80c3345fb993a71fe190fa2f6baa55e4
Closes-Bug: 1842117

commit_message:
Add tests for project users interacting with limits

This commit introduces some tests that explicitly show how project
users are expected to behave with the limits API. A
subsequent patch will clean up the now obsolete policies in the
policy.v3cloudsample.json policy file.

Related-Bug: 1805880
Closes-Bug: 1818736

Change-Id: I12d1200d8a11cadcc4f7b2604d51d8e5c73ea4b7

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Volume Retype Replication fix

Fixes for volume retype with replication:
1)Added missing metro_bias flag when enabling replication during
retype.
2)Added missing force flag when disabling replication during retype
with an attached volume.

Change-Id: I726acbbfe756c82a2b906c1ca45033a0bbc2b6fb

Minimal diff from Train, just highlighting what was implemented (or partially implemented) in Train, and history update:

---

>    Placement), close deficiencies in OpenStack SDK while replace invocations
>    into ``python-${service}client`` one at a time, with calls into the SDK's

> Items Implemented In Train

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-26 19:32:00.000000000', 'message': "Spec: Use OpenStack SDK in Nova (Ussuri)

This is a proposal to get rid of Nova's use of python-${service}client
for $service in glance, ironic, neutron, cinder, etc and replace them
with the OpenStack SDK.

Change-Id: I256a43c12a0fd7cf30d7a077616a14dd236a93f7
Previously-approved: Train
Implements: blueprint openstacksdk-in-nova
"}]
commit_message:
Spec: Use OpenStack SDK in Nova (Ussuri)

This is a proposal to get rid of Nova's use of python-${service}client
for $service in glance, ironic, neutron, cinder, etc and replace them
with the OpenStack SDK.

Change-Id: I256a43c12a0fd7cf30d7a077616a14dd236a93f7
Previously-approved: Train
Implements: blueprint openstacksdk-in-nova

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-09 17:09:48.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: coverage job changes

WIP while OS_TEST_TIMEOUT is 30 since lots of libvirt
tests seem to be trying to make real connections to
libvirt and rbd and thus timeout eventlet tpool.

Bumps the requirement to 4.3 to drop the PYTHON
hack mentioned in tox.ini.

Moves command line args to the config file.

Adds concurrency option for eventlet and greenlet.

Adds functional tests (and dependencies) to the job
for full coverage.

Change-Id: I2599bf04027fb33ff69316aec440d692b97af9da
'}, {'created': '2019-07-09 20:04:20.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: coverage job changes

WIP while OS_TEST_TIMEOUT is 30 since lots of libvirt
tests seem to be trying to make real connections to
libvirt and rbd and thus timeout eventlet tpool.

Bumps the requirement to 4.3 to drop the PYTHON

commit_message:
WIP: coverage job changes

WIP while OS_TEST_TIMEOUT is 30 since lots of libvirt
tests seem to be trying to make real connections to
libvirt and rbd and thus timeout eventlet tpool.

Bumps the requirement to 4.3 to drop the PYTHON
hack mentioned in tox.ini.

Moves command line args to the config file.

Adds concurrency option for eventlet and greenlet.

Adds functional tests (and dependencies) to the job
for full coverage.

Change-Id: I2599bf04027fb33ff69316aec440d692b97af9da

commit_message:
Add StopWatch profiling to SchedulerManager.select_destinations

This just times how long it takes to get allocation candidates
from placement and then how long it takes to process those
results. The latter could obviously be profiled in a more granular
way (filters/weighers/putting allocations/finding alternates) but
that is not done in this simple change.

I basically just wanted this for some simple scheduler performance
profiling before and after a change is made but don't necessarily
expect this to be merged.

Change-Id: I4bfb7ed570c296f24075993d61ec8b62a208b005

This looks like a latent bug in _destroy_evacuated_instances if the instance has been deleted already. The lazy load query doesn't have deleted=True (or whatever it is that means ignore deleted entirely), so it fails. I think that last is the real bug here: lazy load should work on deleted objects."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-28 13:57:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Run evacuate tests with local/lvm and shared/rbd storage

This integrates the evacuate test script into the live
migration script which sets up two different environments:

1. local disk and lvm volume testing

2. shared ceph storage and rbd volume testing

Change-Id: I389006417259c38476bfa18001e9cbb7669048f1
Related-Bug: #1550919

commit_message:
Don't use quotes in glance swift configuration

glance_store uses bare ConfigParser for swift configuration, that
ceased to strip quotes in PY3. That leads to invalid auth parameters
(e.g. 'project_domain_id': '""') and failure to authenticate.

Current CI process does not hit this issue because Swift backend
is not used.

Change-Id: I6d2c129e6747a3c5fcd2da0c88b0a2135775a914
Closes-bug: #1839772

commit_message:
Bump the openstackdocstheme extension to 1.20

Some options are now automatically configured by the version 1.20:
- project
- html_last_updated_fmt
- latex_engine
- latex_elements
- version
- release.

Change-Id: Ifab1917e7a2743a5c309a1ef3729c87f1a49e727

commit_message:
DVR: Cleanup ml2 dvr portbindings on migration

When a DVR router is migrated from distributed to
centralized, we are unbinding the router from the
agents, but the ml2 distributed portbindings for
the router port still remains intact.

This patch will fix the issue by deleting the
binding entry for multiple hosts.

Closes-Bug: #1718345
Change-Id: If139790eb336ff13b07b094151946af30322ad3e

[{'created': '2019-09-26 09:32:50.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I4a37bdaedec1c905f0b81dc29873ed20f807624d
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I4a37bdaedec1c905f0b81dc29873ed20f807624d

Build both IPv4 and IPv6 image with ``make all``.
Build only IPv4 image with ``make``

'}]
commit_message:
Add possiblity to build IPv6 IPXE iamge

Build both IPv4 and IPv6 image with ``make all``.
Build only IPv4 image with ``make``
Build only IPv6 image with ``make ipxe-boot-ipv6.qcow2``

Also add image file ipxe-boot-ipv6.qcow2 which is the
iPXE image build with IPv6 support enabled.

Change-Id: I9d62ccd75eaacfff819348b600a8c3544ed424ef

commit_message:
Neutron: Update force purge of test project to be less aggressive

This PS updates the os purge of the test project to be an optional
operator driven choice, as they will also need to ensure
the project is unique to neutron testing.

Additionally this updates the purge image to be driven by the
charts values.yaml, as with every other image in OSH.

Change-Id: I46807f7c4922a1b411386641eddbd8957ab56f05
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-25 15:50:12.000000000', 'message': 'New func to get dict-type config with default value

In Train cycle, we moved the definition of default values
to openstack_dashboard/defaults.py. The current code accesses
a dict member using []. It requires operators to define a dict
setting with a full member. This commit introduces a new function
to retrieve a dict-type setting considering default values
defined in openstack_dashboard/defaults.py.

Change-Id: I7ff0ad4bca698aef9c0eba370b0570200a14367a
Related-Bug: #1843104
'}, {'created': '2019-09-26 06:12:55.000000000', 'message': 'Handle partial dict setting

In Train cycle, we moved the definition of default values
to openstack_dashboard/defaults.py. The current code accesses
a dict member using []. It requires operators to define a dict
setting with a full member.

This commit allows to use dict-type settings with partial members.

A new function is introduced to retrieve a dict-type setting
considering default values defined in
{openstack_dashboard,horizon,openstack_auth}/defaults.py

Change-Id: I7ff0ad4bca698aef9c0eba370b0570200a14367a
Closes-Bug: #1843104
'}]
commit_message:
Handle partial dict setting

In Train cycle, we moved the definition of default values
to openstack_dashboard/defaults.py. The current code accesses
a dict member using []. It requires operators to define a dict
setting with a full member.

This commit allows to use dict-type settings with partial members.

A new function is introduced to retrieve a dict-type setting
considering default values defined in
{openstack_dashboard,horizon,openstack_auth}/defaults.py

Change-Id: I7ff0ad4bca698aef9c0eba370b0570200a14367a
Closes-Bug: #1843104

[{'created': '2019-09-25 08:41:57.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I58eb75a970fa2d8cd35fcdc8d8022fd7fc6169cc
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I58eb75a970fa2d8cd35fcdc8d8022fd7fc6169cc

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-19 19:31:45.000000000', 'message': 'Keystone: allow probes configuration

Probe configuration is now available for keystone for both liveness and
readiness checks.

This allows the user to configure the initialDelaySeconds, periodSeconds,
timeoutSeconds, successThreshold and failureThreshold of the keystone-api
probes.

A new section in the values.yaml is introduced to eb able to override it.
Existing configuration have not changed as the values are set to the
previous values or to the default ones if they werent configured before.

Change-Id: I1f0e0a1ff9cd10c5acbec33af87aa9e59959b2d2
'}, {'created': '2019-09-19 20:28:41.000000000', 'message': 'Keystone: allow probes configuration

commit_message:
Keystone: allow probes configuration

Probe configuration is now available for keystone for both liveness and
readiness checks.

Change-Id: I1f0e0a1ff9cd10c5acbec33af87aa9e59959b2d2

messages:
[{'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-09-02 15:27:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-09-03 11:30:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-09-03 11:58:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11880, 'date': '2019-09-10 02:13:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Ivan, we noticed the PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: in horizon log in our cloud when we added plugins into horizon and didn't set the policy permission right. The exception can cause intermittent left nav menu missing for horizon. Think this fix will avoid that problem for the UI. However I think it would be better to LOG.error (ex) so we know what policy file has problem."}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-09-10 09:32:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the feedback, Gloria!'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-09-26 15:25:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-09-26 15:28:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Ideally this should be handled in oslo.policy, but a workaround in horizon makes sense. Let's improve oslo.config in Ussuri release.

One minor nit inline."}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-09-26 15:35:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-09-26 15:44:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-09-26 15:46:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-09-26 16:06:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11880, 'date': '2019-09-26 16:51:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Thanks for the fix! LGTM'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-09-26 17:18:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-02 15:27:51.000000000', 'message': "Handle Permission Denied for policy files

oslo.policy doesn't handle Permission Denied error during file
parsing. This patch just ignores IOError exceptions to fallback to
the default behaviour.

Change-Id: I87c2862e6e3a3f42d231552b00dc02364d6fa14f
"}, {'created': '2019-09-26 15:25:22.000000000', 'message': "Handle Permission Denied for policy files

commit_message:
Handle Permission Denied for policy files

oslo.policy doesn't handle Permission Denied error during file
parsing. This patch just ignores IOError exceptions to fallback to
the default behaviour.

Closes-Bug: #1845523
Change-Id: I87c2862e6e3a3f42d231552b00dc02364d6fa14f

commit_message:
ng-9: Driver for nodegroup operations

This adds the support for creating and deleting worker  nodegroups
using different stack per nodegroup. In order to be backwards
compatible, default nodegroups will remain in one stack.

Having this in mind cluster status is now calculated aggregating the
statuses of the underlying stacks.

Change-Id: I97839ab8495ed5d860785dff1f6e3cc59b6a9ff7

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-16 07:56:45.000000000', 'message': 'Support for Neutron Helm test cleanup and reset for abnormal failures

Rally usually cleans up all its resources in normal executions - normal
test success cases and normal test failure cases. But the generic cleanup
does not work well for out of the system failures like process
interruptions, pod failures, disaster cleanup etc.
This is a known issue in rally-openstack. -
"Current generic mechanism is nice but it doesn't work enough well in real life.
And in cases of existing users, persistence context
and disaster cleanups it doesn't work well."

Hence, if we shall face above such issues, it is becoming impossible
to run "helm test neutron" again because of the stale data
and different quota limits mentioned in the values.yaml.
Hence we need to purge the stale data from the "test"
project as well as reset the quota limit for such scenarios.

For the normal executions, this patch has to do nothing,
but for unexpected failures, this patch will purge the stale data
from test project and reset the quota as defined in
values.yaml for the next run.

Change-Id: I3f6851582e2ac1aa1d375fcd13c07f4f57f45dc8

commit_message:
Support for Neutron Helm test cleanup and reset for abnormal failures

Rally usually cleans up all its resources in normal executions - normal
test success cases and normal test failure cases. But the generic cleanup
does not work well for out of the system failures like process
interruptions, pod failures, disaster cleanup etc.
This is a known issue in rally-openstack. -
"Current generic mechanism is nice but it doesn't work enough well in real life.
And in cases of existing users, persistence context
and disaster cleanups it doesn't work well."

Hence, if we shall face above such issues, it is becoming impossible
to run "helm test neutron" again because of the stale data
and different quota limits mentioned in the values.yaml.
Hence we need to purge the stale data from the "test"
project as well as reset the quota limit for such scenarios.

For the normal executions, this patch has to do nothing,
but for unexpected failures, this patch will purge the stale data
from test project and reset the quota as defined in
values.yaml for the next run.

Change-Id: I3f6851582e2ac1aa1d375fcd13c07f4f57f45dc8

[{'created': '2019-09-25 18:28:25.000000000', 'message': 'Update log-driver value for podman

Depending on the podman version, "json-file" is set to noop and makes
podman crash (true for at least podman 1.4.1), while older versions
re-add this json-file as an alias to k8s-file (true since 1.4.3).

Ensuiring we're using k8s-file will prevent issues depending on the
podman version.

Relates to https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1754416
Closes-Bug: #1844856

Change-Id: I70eba8af06741ed81173689a03c4867421917cd6
(cherry picked from commit 0976e4eeb3421873ad487d01ce85b0ec94d735ce)
'}]
commit_message:
Update log-driver value for podman

Depending on the podman version, "json-file" is set to noop and makes
podman crash (true for at least podman 1.4.1), while older versions
re-add this json-file as an alias to k8s-file (true since 1.4.3).

Ensuiring we're using k8s-file will prevent issues depending on the
podman version.

Relates to https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1754416
Closes-Bug: #1844856

Change-Id: I70eba8af06741ed81173689a03c4867421917cd6
(cherry picked from commit 0976e4eeb3421873ad487d01ce85b0ec94d735ce)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-09 15:22:12.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Deprecate [placement]/policy_file config option

TODO: tests, update docs and PolicyFixture

The [placement]/policy_file option was necessary when placement
was in nova since nova uses the standard [oslo_policy]/policy_file
option for defining custom policy rules. Now that placement is
extracted (+1 release) we can deprecate the placement-specific
option and use the standard [oslo_policy]/policy_file option as well.

The tricky thing with this is both options define a default value
but those values are different, and neither need to exist or can
exist but be empty and we'll use policy defaults from code. So some
logic is necessary for detecting which option we should pass to the
oslo.policy Enforcer object. We prefer to use [oslo_policy]/policy_file
if it exists but will fallback to use [placement]/policy_file for
backward compatibility. We also check for a couple of edge cases to
try and detect misconfiguration and usage of the deprecated option.

The config generation docs are updated to include the [oslo_policy]
options as well as registering the options from that library for
runtime code.

Change-Id: Ifb14d2c14b17fc5bcdf7d124744ac2e1b58fd063
Story: #2005171
Task: #29913
"}, {'created': '2019-09-12 22:19:01.000000000', 'message': "Deprecate [placement]/policy_file config option

The [placement]/policy_file option was necessary when placement
was in nova since nova uses the standard [oslo_policy]/policy_file
option for defining custom policy rules. Now that placement is

option and use the standard [oslo_policy]/policy_file option as well.

The tricky thing with this is both options define a default value
but those values are different, and neither need to exist or can
exist but be empty and we'll use policy defaults from code. So some
logic is necessary for detecting which option we should pass to the
oslo.policy Enforcer object. We prefer to use [oslo_policy]/policy_file
if it exists but will fallback to use [placement]/policy_file for
backward compatibility. We also check for a couple of edge cases to
try and detect misconfiguration and usage of the deprecated option.

The config generation docs are updated to include the [oslo_policy]
options as well as registering the options from that library for
runtime code.

Change-Id: Ifb14d2c14b17fc5bcdf7d124744ac2e1b58fd063
Story: #2005171
Task: #29913
"}]
commit_message:
Deprecate [placement]/policy_file config option

The [placement]/policy_file option was necessary when placement
was in nova since nova uses the standard [oslo_policy]/policy_file
option for defining custom policy rules. Now that placement is
extracted (+1 release) we can deprecate the placement-specific
option and use the standard [oslo_policy]/policy_file option as well.

The tricky thing with this is both options define a default value
but those values are different, and neither need to exist or can
exist but be empty and we'll use policy defaults from code. So some
logic is necessary for detecting which option we should pass to the
oslo.policy Enforcer object. We prefer to use [oslo_policy]/policy_file
if it exists but will fallback to use [placement]/policy_file for
backward compatibility. We also check for a couple of edge cases to
try and detect misconfiguration and usage of the deprecated option.

The config generation docs are updated to include the [oslo_policy]
options as well as registering the options from that library for
runtime code.

Change-Id: Ifb14d2c14b17fc5bcdf7d124744ac2e1b58fd063
Story: #2005171
Task: #29913

commit_message:
Fix pagination does not speed up queries bug

This patch modifies the database api layer to fix the pagination
slowness bug, which causes a delay while the administrator tries
to list shares using the `--limit` option.
This change was tested in a very busy environment with 800 shares.
Before the change, the operation took about 25 seconds to be
finished. Now, the operation takes about 3 seconds in the same
environment.

Change-Id: I89659452b0e033631f1318a2eabb7e120c9e5743
Closes-bug: #1795463

[{'created': '2019-09-21 07:44:42.000000000', 'message': "Fix timeout when compute server was soft-deleted

When set 'reclaim_instance_interval' larger than 0, share server
was deleted cause that the server exists until
reclaim_instance_interval. This patch checks status 'soft_deleted'
of instance to avoid the timeout.

Change-Id: Ib481c1699b19ee8c37473081f1aec780ed384e9d
Closes-Bug: #1844596
"}, {'created': '2019-09-25 13:30:02.000000000', 'message': "Fix timeout when compute server was soft-deleted

When set 'reclaim_instance_interval' larger than 0, share server
was deleted cause that the server exists until
reclaim_instance_interval. This patch checks status 'soft_deleted'
of instance to avoid the timeout.

Change-Id: Ib481c1699b19ee8c37473081f1aec780ed384e9d
Closes-Bug: #1844596
"}]
commit_message:
Fix timeout when compute server was soft-deleted

When set 'reclaim_instance_interval' larger than 0, share server
was deleted cause that the server exists until
reclaim_instance_interval. This patch checks status 'soft_deleted'
of instance to avoid the timeout.

Change-Id: Ib481c1699b19ee8c37473081f1aec780ed384e9d
Closes-Bug: #1844596

messages:
[{'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-06-10 06:31:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-06-19 19:15:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-06-20 05:18:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-06-20 05:19:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27822, 'date': '2019-06-28 10:04:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-07-03 15:02:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-07-12 05:57:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-07-12 05:57:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27822, 'date': '2019-07-12 05:59:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-07-25 14:01:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-07-25 14:45:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Honestly I wonder what kind of useful thing this change brings.....

Although showing ID might be consistent as other tables from the point of view that some information per item is displayed in the delete form, IMHO ID is hard to distinguish and ID does not provide useful information in the delete confirmation dialog.

Imagine, you have tens of RBAC policies. If you are provided ID of RBAC policies to be deleted, can you really check them?

IMHO it would be much more useful if more summary information of RBAC policies are provided instead of UUID (from UX perspective).

From my above though, as of now, I don't give any positive/negative score."}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-07-29 17:38:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Honestly I wonder what kind of useful thing this change brings.....
 > 
 > Although showing ID might be consistent as other tables from the
 > point of view that some information per item is displayed in the
 > delete form, IMHO ID is hard to distinguish and ID does not provide
 > useful information in the delete confirmation dialog.
 > 
 > Imagine, you have tens of RBAC policies. If you are provided ID of
 > RBAC policies to be deleted, can you really check them?
 > 
 > IMHO it would be much more useful if more summary information of
 > RBAC policies are provided instead of UUID (from UX perspective).
 > 
 > From my above though, as of now, I don't give any positive/negative
 > score.

First of all, I have pushed this patch to maintain consistency with other table forms.
Do you mean something like this "You have selected <rbac_policy_id> of <object_name>" 
Thoughts?
Kindly Suggest?'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-07-30 04:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

My main point is it is less useful to show UUID in the confirmation dialog.
While you talk about the consistency of tables, most other tables use "name" (rather than "ID"). horizon tries to avoid "ID" and to use name or meaningful summary (if "name" is not provided).

If you all think UUID in the confirmation dialog is useful, feel free to land it.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-09-10 11:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I advised UUID is not user-friendly in IRC and he said he will update it [1], but the updated version has not come yet, so -1 now.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-horizon/%23openstack-horizon.2019-08-08.log.html#t2019-08-08T08:23:31'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-09-10 12:17:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I advised UUID is not user-friendly in IRC and he said he will
 > update it [1], but the updated version has not come yet, so -1 now.
 > 
 > [1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-horizon/%23openstack-horizon.2019-08-08.log.html#t2019-08-08T08:23:31

Sorry for the delayed response, actually I don't have too much idea about the 'RBAC' and your comment is not cleared to me. Could you update this patch acc. to you or push another patch to fix this bug."}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-09-26 14:04:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-09-26 17:19:34.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Show RBAC Policy Id on deletion Confirmation prompt

When we delete rbac policies under admin panel, Confirmation
window does not display selected rbac policies ID. This patch
fix the issue.

Change-Id: I260236b1f3c237f7b0723c4fecacd98e972533cd
Closes-Bug: #1821836

[{'created': '2019-09-26 09:44:12.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I917efb9f73cf6c1ea10e1d69d449b103fc9ed437
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I917efb9f73cf6c1ea10e1d69d449b103fc9ed437

commit_message:
Fix distro install on openSUSE

With Train openSUSE is switching the openstack packages to use Python 3.
This means that we need to use the python3 variants of python-module
packages.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/683123

commit_message:
Retrieve compatible share servers using subnet id

When searching for compatible share servers, the share manager now
looks for share servers that matches the destination host and the
related share network subnet id.

Change-Id: I62b80e24df443789359bb8d7ceaaf3d704366bc9

subject: Amend "Configure max number of volumes to attach" spec
messages:
[{'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-09-13 18:51:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-09-25 09:37:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-09-26 15:53:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(2 comments)

A couple of nits inline but probably not worth forcing a respin of this. Specs shouldn't really be the end-all docs so hopefully the config option help is sufficient:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#compute.max_disk_devices_to_attach"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-13 18:51:08.000000000', 'message': 'Amend "Configure max number of volumes to attach" spec

Update the spec to reflect what was actually implemented.

TL;DR is during implementation, we found that the old limit in the
libvirt driver of 26 was a limit on the maximum number of disk
devices allowed to attach to a single instance, including the root
disk (and any other disks). So "volumes" wasn't really correct for
representing what is being limited and the terminology was changed
to "disk devices".

Related to blueprint conf-max-attach-volumes

Change-Id: I3152d0ed64709495ff7f13ff1d75ce62558a8731
'}]
commit_message:
Amend "Configure max number of volumes to attach" spec

Update the spec to reflect what was actually implemented.

TL;DR is during implementation, we found that the old limit in the
libvirt driver of 26 was a limit on the maximum number of disk
devices allowed to attach to a single instance, including the root
disk (and any other disks). So "volumes" wasn't really correct for
representing what is being limited and the terminology was changed
to "disk devices".

Related to blueprint conf-max-attach-volumes

Change-Id: I3152d0ed64709495ff7f13ff1d75ce62558a8731

[{'created': '2019-09-26 09:43:13.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I06e17e2ea5ca42d85beb94b1f02f3078a11e8eb2

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

commit_message:
Add support for pcmk resource op defaults

This adds support for setting op defaults via pcs.
Tested via:
include ::pacemaker::resource_op_defaults

A) No defaults set to start with:
[root@controller-0 pacemaker]# pcs resource op defaults
No defaults set

B) Hiera key to pass a new default:
[root@controller-0 pacemaker]# hiera -c /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml pacemaker::resource_op_defaults::defaults
{"timeout_test"=>{"name"=>"timeout", "value"=>"60s"}}

C) Puppet apply:
[root@controller-0 pacemaker]# puppet apply /tmp/test.pp
Notice: Compiled catalog for controller-0.redhat.local in environment production in 0.06 seconds
Notice: /Stage[main]/Pacemaker::Resource_op_defaults/Pcmk_resource_op_default[timeout_test]/ensure: created
Notice: Applied catalog in 2.89 seconds

D) Correct results
[root@controller-0 pacemaker]# pcs resource op defaults
timeout: 60s

E) Change value:
[root@controller-0 pacemaker]# hiera -c /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml pacemaker::resource_op_defaults::defaults
{"timeout_test"=>{"name"=>"timeout", "value"=>"65s"}}

[root@controller-0 pacemaker]# puppet apply /tmp/test.pp

[root@controller-0 pacemaker]# pcs resource op defaults
timeout: 65s

F) Idempotency:
[root@controller-0 pacemaker]# puppet apply /tmp/test.pp
Notice: Compiled catalog for controller-0.redhat.local in environment production in 0.05 seconds
Notice: Applied catalog in 0.97 seconds

Change-Id: Id72941260c264081cec253382d8e4c975c4a6104

commit_message:
Revert "Raise NotFound error when retrieved by not uuid"

In the early days of OpenStack, user and project ids were not
uuids, but auto-incremented integers.

Since those early days, many operators fought long battles
against the unrelenting OpenStack behemoth.

Only those heroic operators who emerged victorious from the
brutal upgrade battles can show the scars of those integer
user and project ids like badges of honour.

Closes-Bug: #1842004
Change-Id: I0c3e3465e8e7499c94d1a82b7295aeec13955e55
(cherry picked from commit c238b519f3e10ba6aa119b5ebc2bf30b2610bf16)

commit_message:
Fix listing security groups when no rules

When listing security groups in the dashboard and
one or more security groups had no rules it failed
because python throws a KeyError.

This commit changes the neutron API wrapper in horizon
to ensure ensure rule information in SG always exists.

Closes-Bug: #1840465
Co-Authored-By: Tobias Urdin <tobias.urdin@binero.se>
Change-Id: I6e05a7dc6b6655514ee2bff6bd327da86f13900a
(cherry picked from commit cdb191ec83f86dffade56be07ca53077d7c78b14)

commit_message:
Fixes IPv6 static route addition

This change fixes the form validation error while adding
IPv6 static routes to a router through the OpenStack Dashboard.
Unit tests to cover this action have also been added.

Change-Id: Ied0fd27dbbc33a98617c049977539c5b3c71cdfe
Closes-Bug: #1523341
(cherry picked from commit 43034cbb2330c476325edd1c6854dd93a30d8814)

[{'created': '2019-09-11 02:53:20.000000000', 'message': 'Updated max-width to be dynamic for .member class

When member name is longer than $members-list-item-width
(130px) in members list (for example, project group in Edit
Project), current text-overflow will put ... (ellipsis) at
the end of the name and name will be truncated.

Updated the styling of .member class to make max-width
dynamic 80% and wrap the name in case it is really long.

commit_message:
Updated max-width to be dynamic for .member class

When member name is longer than $members-list-item-width
(130px) in members list (for example, project group in Edit
Project), current text-overflow will put ... (ellipsis) at
the end of the name and name will be truncated.

Updated the styling of .member class to make max-width
dynamic 80% and wrap the name in case it is really long.

Change-Id: Ic295a9b1e7fd3525c633d51a60054e713da6a657
Closes-bug: #1843480

If we need a way to get information from a backend for these checks, we should look at how that might be designed via a cinder-spec."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-08-08 15:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review+1 by Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-08-08 15:38:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

> I'm fairly sure that loading and running volume drivers is outside
 > the scope of what the cinder-status command should be doing.
 > 
 > If we need a way to get information from a backend for these
 > checks, we should look at how that might be designed via a
 > cinder-spec.

I know Jay asked for this, but I have to agree with Eric. It would be great having a check ahead of time to make sure an operator new there was a problem, but it's not really an OpenStack upgrade issue so much as an environment issue. So not something that a deployment can fix by making a change in cinder.conf, but something that they need to address outside of Cinder services to work with the new release.

I think as long as the compatiblity requirement was listed in a release note for Train and that there is a check on driver start, that should be enough."}, {'account_id': 21976, 'date': '2019-08-08 15:58:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Unisphere version check

Adding in a validation check that will output whether a user's
running Unisphere instance meets the minimum version
requirements for PowerMax Driver release.

Change-Id: I2e9e6a3a13b92406845b1aa70d76e017dd67e831

Remove duplicated "for" loop

The very same loop was called twice, the only difference being the
logging.

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Metro Volume Metadata change

Change the metadata for Metro Active replicated volumes to
show a replication mode of 'Metro' instead of 'Active'

Change-Id: I4c87f555cd76dee2c86ae51b9e5d310a864d6116

commit_message:
Fix compatibility with Pint 0.5

Conversion from Quantity to int/long was added only in 0.5.2.

Change-Id: I23f93d29a0624b77f4624c6af530971eb6a4c01b
(cherry picked from commit 386654f602c86495515811dd741652a3b0292fd3)

subject: Update master for stable/train
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-25 08:50:14.000000000', 'message': 'Update master for stable/train

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/train.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/train.

Change-Id: I78973b501ebddf630fb8c45e47763222f3c3226e
Sem-Ver: feature
'}]
commit_message:
Update master for stable/train

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/train.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/train.

Change-Id: I78973b501ebddf630fb8c45e47763222f3c3226e
Sem-Ver: feature
